member.name: T:Imagin.Controls.Common.TreeViewRowHeader
member.summary: A container used to present a TreeViewItem's header.

member.name: F:Imagin.Controls.Common.Extensions.ListBoxExtensions.IsDirectionalSelectionEnabledProperty
member.summary: Determines whether or not directional keys can be used to select items; intended for complex views where items are organized in both rows and columns.
member.pseudo: If up or left is clicked and nothing is selected, select first. If bottom or right is clicked and nothing is selected, select last. If first is selected and clicking left or up, select last. If last is selected and clicking right or down, select first.

member.name: F:Imagin.Controls.Common.Extensions.ListBoxExtensions.SelectionWrapProperty
member.summary: Determines whether or not selections made with directional keys "wrap" ends.
member.remarks: IsDirectionalSelectionEnabled must be set to true.

member.summary: One item may be checked.

member.name: F:Imagin.Controls.Common.Extensions.MenuItemSelectionMode.SingleOrNone
member.summary: Either one or no items may be checked.

member.name: F:Imagin.Controls.Common.Extensions.MenuItemSelectionMode.Multiple
member.summary: Any number of items may be checked; equivalent to not specifying a group name.

member.name: M:Imagin.Controls.Common.Extensions.MenuItemExtensions.OnChecked(System.Object,System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs)
member.remarks: Let's assume the MenuItem was generated from a collection of enum values. The data context for the MenuItem would be = to a unique enum value. The GroupSource should be bound to a property somewhere that stores a reference to the current enum value. When checking a MenuItem, it is necessary to update the GroupSource so the source reflects the checked value. The GroupSource should only update when an initial value has been set.

member.name: M:Imagin.Controls.Common.AdvancedTextBox.OnPreviewMouseLeftButtonDownHandled(System.Windows.Input.MouseButtonEventArgs,System.Type[])
member.remarks: Normally, focus is obtained when left mouse button is pressed. When clicking buttons that might be contained in the template, focus is obtained first, thus, requiring a second click in order to actually click the button. To prevent this, we must detect whether or not the intention is to click a button or focus. Therefore, if the element clicked IS a button, handle the focus; otherwise, focus!
